com.github.parboiled1.grappa.matchers.join

Class JoinMatcher

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.parboiled.trees.ImmutableGraphNode<Matcher>
      • org.parboiled.matchers.AbstractMatcher
        • org.parboiled.matchers.CustomDefaultLabelMatcher<JoinMatcher>
          • com.github.parboiled1.grappa.matchers.join.JoinMatcher
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Cloneable, Matcher, Rule, GraphNode<Matcher>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BoundedBothJoinMatcher, BoundedDownJoinMatcher, BoundedUpJoinMatcher, ExactMatchesJoinMatcher

    @Beta
public abstract class JoinMatcher
extends CustomDefaultLabelMatcher<JoinMatcher>
    A joining matcher

    Such a matcher has two submatchers: a "joined" matcher and a "joining" matcher.

    This matcher will run cycles through both of these; the first will be a run of the "joined" matcher, subsequent cycles will be ("joining", "joined").

    Therefore:

    • one cycle is joined;
    • two cycles is joined, joining, joined;
    • etc etc.

    This matcher will correctly reset the index to the last successful match; for instance, if the match sequence is joined, joining, joined, joining and two cycles are enough, it will reset the index to before the last joining so that subsequent matchers can proceed from there.

    It is forbidden for the "joining" matcher to match an empty sequence. Unfortunately, due to current limitations, this can only be detected at runtime (but also by the CanMatchEmptyVisitor when used).

    This matcher is not built directly; its build is initiated by a JoinMatcherBootstrap. Using the JoinParser base parser mentioned above, here is how you would, for instance, build a rule where you want a sequence of three digits separated by dots:

         Rule threeDigitsExactly()
     {
         return join(digit()).using('.').times(3);
     }
    See Also:
    JoinMatcherBootstrap
